title-group.article-title: Response to “Extraesophageal Reflux Is Still NOT the Same Disorder as Gastroesophageal Reflux,” from Gregory N. Postma and Milan Amin

body.p: We are very appreciative of these comments and agree with their insight and thoughtfulness. This article was preceded by a critical review of the evidence-based clinical practice guidelines on reflux disease,1 also predominantly from the gastroenterology and primary care literature. Our article on the synthesis of a protocol has more prominent representation from otolaryngology, but only 1 study was based on a systematic review of the literature, emphasizing a need for further study and consensus.

There are certainly differences between the classic patient with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and extraesophageal reflux (EER) or laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR). Because the scientific and clinical literature is limited, we relied on the existing body of knowledge with the understanding that EER and LPR are atypical variants of the classic GERD model. It is also important to recognize that although there are many similarities (such as regurgitation of gastric contents), many aspects to EER/LPR may make it a physiologically distinct disease. These include the potential for seeding of pepsin in the laryngeal mucosa with or without subsequent reactivation by more reflux,2 the local immune response in the larynx to the reflux insult,3 the presence of heterotopic gastric mucosa in the esophagus,4 the potential for local acid production,5 heightened cricopharyngeal tone, and others.

Drs Postma and Amin shared their concern that patients with moderate to severe EER have a higher incidence of esophageal pathology, including Barrett esophagus, and this should prompt a lower tolerance to perform esophageal screening. One contribution of our article includes the idea of a protocol based on alarm symptoms and risk stratification. We agree that the alarm symptoms listed in Table 3 should more prominently include those associated with EER/LPR, which would drive the patient care protocol into a higher risk decision process. Transnasal esophagoscopy (TNE) is an important tool in evaluating the esophagus in such patients and should also be more prominently considered in the protocol.

Protocols should offer clinical guidance, predominantly to the primary care physician, who, in the case of reflux disease, provides care to 79% of patients. They should not circumvent the experience and wisdom of a skilled specialist but should benefit from his or her input. We propose an interdisciplinary working group to help evolve this protocol, with broader input from experts such as Drs Postma and Amin, and hope that with time the clinical evidence associated with EER and LPR has a greater influence in this pathway.
